Francisco is requesting a Kiva loan to invest in the construction of a room for his daughter so that she will have more privacy and greater comfort. One of his dreams is for his children to have the amenities they deserve.

loans.use: To build a room for his daughter.

loans.name: Celso

texts.en:
Celso G. is from the village of Poblacion, Mahinog, Camiguin Province. He is 46 years old and single. To make a living, he owns and operates a service-based business, providing hairdressing and beauty services in his beauty parlor to local community members. He has been engaged in his business for over twenty-seven years and earns approximately $250 a month for these activities.

In 2010, Celso joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve his living situation and ability to engage in business activities. He has successfully repaid a previous loan of 4,000 PHP from HSPFI. This previous loan was used to purchase tools needed to provide service. 

Celso is requesting a new loan of 5,000 PHP which will be used to purchase items needed to expand his services, like hair solutions. This will be his 2nd loan from HSPFI. He plans to use the additional revenue generated to improve his business. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase items needed to expand his services, like hair solutions

loans.name: Erlinda

texts.en:
Erlinda is 65 years old. She is a married woman from the town of Bunawan, Agusan Del Sur. She is a farmer and has been growing rice for more than 30 years. She and her husband, who is also a farmer, work together in tilling the land and keeping their crops healthy.

Erlinda asked for a loan so she could purchase seeds, fertilizers and other farm inputs that she needs. She hopes for her farming business to grow. Erlinda works hard to feed her family and keep them healthy.

loans.use: to purchase seeds, fertilizers and other farm inputs

loans.name: Ana Bienvenida

texts.es:
Ana de 33 años, es una mujer trabajadora que quiere sacar adelante a su familia ya que desde muy joven trabaja como empleada domestica.

En la actualidad trabaja en una casa como empleada y esa familia la acepta como una persona más. Ella se encarga de los quehaceres domésticos y en la noche cuida a sus hijo tiene 2 de 16 y 8 años. 

Tiene muchas aspiracion para seguir trabajando y darle una nueva oportunidad a sus hijos. Con el préstamo quiere comprar cemento y arena para adecuar su vivienda y mejorar el nivel de su familia y tener una vida sana y prospera.
texts.en:
Ana is 33 years old and is a hardworking woman who wants to get her family ahead.  She’s been working as a maid since she was a young woman, and currently works as an employee in a home.  That family accepts her as one of their own.  She takes care of the housework and cares for the children, 2x 16 year olds and one 8 year old.

She has many aspirations to continue working and give a better life to her children.  She will use the money from this loan to buy cement and sand in order to make improvements to her home and improve the life of her family, so that they can have a prosperous and successful life.

loans.use: to make home improvements

loans.name: Naftalus

texts.en:
Naftalus, aged 42, is married with two children. He runs a carpentry business and has been in this business for 15 years.

This is his second loan from KADET LTD and he has managed to successfully pay the previous loan well.


He will use the profits from his business to educate his children. He hopes to open a classic workshop.

loans.use: To purchase tools and timber

loans.name: Akouele

texts.fr: Revendeuse ambulante des produits de premières nécessités (spaguetti, riz…) Akouélé  âgée de 33ans est mariée à un tailleur  et mère de deux enfants. Cette activité qu’elle a commencée en 2008 lui permet de ramener la croûte journalière  de sa famille car elle tient énormément à son rôle de mère au foyer. Toute son activité est basée au pays.
texts.en: Akouélé is a 33 year-old mother of two who is married to a tailor. She conducts door-to-door sales of staple foods (spaghetti, rice etc). She entered this trade in 2008, and the money that it generates enables her to see to her family's needs - in her eyes this is fundamental to her role as a mother. All of her business is generated in and around her area.

loans.use: to purchase staple food products (spaghetti, rice etc)

loans.name: Sonangnon Group

texts.fr: SONANGNON est un groupement constitué de dix sept personnes et dont la présidente (celle qui a la main levée sur la photo) est nommée Tatiana. Les membres du groupe résident dans le même village au Bénin. Dans le but d’augmenter leur fonds de roulement, ce groupement sollicite pour la première fois, un crédit auprès de ALIDé. Née en 1988 au Bénin, Tatiana vit ensemble avec son mari et ses enfants dans une ville du Bénin. Tatiana est mariée à un certain Bruno et a deux enfants, dont un est scolarisé. Tatiana assure ensemble avec son mari les différentes charges de la maison. Tatiana n'a fréquenté que l'école primaire. Depuis environs sept ans, Tatiana prépare de la nourriture (riz accompagné de sauce)qu'elle vend dans un marché du Bénin. De façon secondaire, Tatiana vend des chaussures. Cette activité lui génère des revenus l'aidant à contribuer aux dépenses familiales. Tatiana achète ses produits dans l'un des marchés du Bénin. Ce premier prêt permettra certainement à Tatiana et aux autres membres du groupement SONANGNON de rehausser le niveau de leur activité et d’accroître leur clientèle et leur revenu.
texts.en:
SONANGNON is a group composed of seventeen persons whose president (the one in the photo with her hand raised) is named Tatiana. The group members reside in the same village in Benin. With the goal of increasing their working capital, this group is requesting a loan from ALIDé for the first time. Born in 1988 in Benin, Tatiana lives together with her husband and children in a city in Benin. She is married to a man named Bruno and has two children, one of whom is in school. Along with her husband, she ensures that the different household expenses are covered. 

Tatiana attended primary school only. For about seven years, she has made food (rice served with sauce) that she sells at a market in Benin. Secondarily, she sells shoes. This business generates the revenues which help her to meet family expenses. She purchases her goods at one of the markets in Benin. 

This initial loan will certainly enable Tatiana and the other members of the group SONANGNON to boost their level of business and to grow their customer base and their revenues.

loans.use: to buy 2 sacks of rice, a box of canned tomatoes, and some condiments.

loans.name: Nuch

texts.en:
Nuch, 57 years old, is a farmer with her husband. Their income is $3 per day. They have 4 children and all of them are working in the factory. 

Every month, Nuch has to spend around $75 for every expense in the family. She would like to request a loan of $1000 to buy a Tok Tok (a motorbike with a cart attached). This will allow her son to earn money because his work earns a very small income. When she can save some money, she wants to get a place to feed the chickens at home. She would also like to send her children to school to get a specific skill with which they are able to support themselves.

loans.use: to buy a Tok Tok (a motorbike with a cart attached).

loans.name: Junielka Del Rosario

texts.es: La señora Jinielka tiene 25 años,  posee un hijo menor a su cargo. Su negocio es la venta de ropa nueva y raspaditas, los cuales distribuye de manera ambulante, pues es así que ha obtenido los ingresos necesarios para mantener a su familia. Ella inicio con este negocio primeramente trabajando con la venta de raspaditas y al mismo tiempo tenía que estudiar, con mucho sacrificio ha logrado todo lo que tiene. Trabaja todos los días desde las 7 de la mañana hasta las 9 de la noche, por lo que diariamente tiene que recorrer diferentes lugares para vender sus prendas de vestir y raspaditas. Ella actualmente está solicitando este crédito para invertirlo en la compra de pantalones, camisas, faldas, vestidos y trajes. Su sueño, es que a través de las ganancias ofrecidas por el negocio pueda brindarle una educación universitaria a su hijo.
texts.en:
Señora Jinielka is 25 years old and has a young child under her care. Her business is the sale of new clothes and lottery scratch tickets, which she distributes as a street vendor. In this way she has been able to make the necessary income to support her family.   

She began this business working primarily with the sale of lottery scratch tickets while at the same time she had to study. She has gained everything she has through a lot of sacrifice. She works every day from seven in the morning to nine at night. Each day she has to go round to many places to sell her clothing items and lottery scratch tickets. 

She is currently requesting this loan to invest in the purchase of pants, shirts, skirts, dresses and suits. Her dream is that with the profits made through the business she will be able to provide her child with a university education.

loans.use: to purchase pants, shirts, skirts, dresses and suits.

loans.name: Grace

texts.en:
Grace is 22 years old and lives in the Philippines. She is married with three children. 

Grace has a shop that sells electronic loads used for mobile payments on the GLOBE & SMART networks. She has had this business for two years. She has requested a loan for PHP 7,000 to buy electronic loads for several networks.

Grace has been a member of HSPFI since 2010. In the future, Grace hopes to improve her business.

loans.use: to buy electronic loads for mobile payments on several networks

loans.name: Virginia

texts.en:
Virginia is 59 years old, married, and has two children. She is a very hard-working entrepreneur. Virginia has a sari-sari (variety) store in the Philippines. Virginia requested a 17,000 PHP loan through NWTF to purchase more items like canned goods, snacks, and other miscellaneous items to sell in her store.

Virginia has been in this business for 10 years. In the future, Virginia would like to save enough money so she can afford to send her children to college.

loans.use: to purchase canned goods, snacks, and other miscellaneous items to sell in her store

loans.name: Maribel

texts.es:
La Sra. Maribel pertenece al Banco Comunal “Las Aguerridas II”, del Distrito de Tarapoto, Provincia y Departamento de San Martín. Es conviviente, tiene 28 años y 02 hijas de 04 y 02 años de edad, estudiantes de nivel inicial.
A los 20 años empezó a  trabajar como secretaria en una institución, tuvo su familia e hijas y dejó el trabajo  para dedicarse a su hogar, por iniciativa propia y con el apoyo de su pareja, decide vender ceviche con mariscos (plato típico de la región) en su casa.  Su préstamo inicial fue de S/. 300.00 Nuevos soles. Actualmente ofrece su producto  a familiares, amigos, vecinos y público en general, poco a poco fue ganando más clientela y está muy contenta.
Con este nuevo préstamo de S/. 1700.00, comprará  más insumos como pescados y mariscos, sacos de yuca, sacos de papa, sacos de choclos, sacos de camotes, sacos de cebolla, sacos de limones y así para preparar sus platos exquisitos y muy agradables.
Maribel es una mujer luchadora y emprendedora,  su sueño es tener su restaurante de pescados y mariscos, está muy agradecida con el Movimiento Manuela Ramos por brindarle la oportunidad de seguir creciendo.
texts.en:
Maribel is a member of the communal bank "Las Aguerridas II" of the district of Tarapoto in the province and department of San Martin. She is married common-law and she is 28 years old. She has 2 daughters, aged 4 and 2 and they are in preschool.

When she was 20 years old she became employed as a secretary in an institution. She formed a family and she had her daughters and she quit her job to take care of their home. Under her own initiative and with her partner's support she started out selling ceviche (a traditional seafood dish of the region) from her house. Her first loan was in the amount of S./300 nuevos soles. She currently sells her product to her family, friends, and neighbors and to the general public. Gradually she has earned more clientele and she is very happy.

With this new loan in the amount of S/.1700 nuevos soles she will purchase more ingredients such as fish, seafood, sacks of yucca, sacks of potatoes, sacks of corns, sacks of sweet potatoes, sacks of onions, and sacks of lemons. This way she will be able to prepare her exquisite and very pleasant recipes.

Maribel is an achieving and enterprising woman whose dream is to have fish and seafood restaurant. She is very thankful to the Manuela Ramos movement (Kiva Field Partner) for providing her with the opportunity to keep growing.

loans.use: to purchase ingredients such as fish and seafood, sacks of yucca, sacks of potatoes, sacks of corn, etc.

loans.name: Luz

texts.en:
This is Luz, 50, a resident of Dasmariñas, Cavite City, Philippines. She is married to Francisco, a maintenance worker and has one child. She, together with her husband, manages their household while operating the business. She continually works hard to provide income for their everyday expenses.

Luz operates a variety store. In the Philippines, a variety store is basically a small convenience store which retails groceries, toiletries and beverages piecemeal to the local neighborhood. It is the place to go to buy one sachet of shampoo, a Php5-worth of cooking oil or an egg. She earns by getting supplies at wholesale prices and selling by the piece. Her store is located adjacent to her house. Her regular customers are her neighbors and the local community. She earns a minimum of 400 Philippine Pesos (PHP) every day.

To help her continue business operations, she is requesting a Php9,000 loan. She will be utilizing the loan to buy groceries, toiletries and beverages to expand her product inventory. She expects a boost in her business income as she expands her business. 

Luz hopes to be able to expand soon, just as she hopes for her husband to have a permanent job. She faithfully meets up with her co-fellowship* members to share stories of her work every week and to draw strength and inspiration from the Word of God she studies.

* All CCT community partners / clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and repay Micro Finance loans.

loans.use: To pay for grocery items and products needed in her business.

loans.name: Anthony

texts.en:
Anthony is a farmer in Litein, South rift Kenya. He has been in farming for 18 years and currently produces milk and tea for the local market with the help of two farmhands. He is married with four children, two of whom are adults and the other two who are still schooling.

Anthony made a 50,000 Kenya shilling (KES) loan request through Kiva partner Juhudi Kilimo to help him construct a zero grazing (stall feeding) unit. He says this would improve his milk output and help him in running his hotel and butchery businesses in the local market and in turn educate his children.

Anthony notes that markets should be improved as they could be a challenge to farming business. He is also advocating for more farmer training.

loans.use: To construct a zero grazing unit.

loans.name: José Luis

texts.es: El señor José Luis y su esposa  son unas personas emprendedoras que les gusta el negocio por tal motivo pensó en poner venta de ropa usada  en una de las colonias de la ciudad, el cual se podrían desarrollar como unos buenos negociantes. Con el negocio ya tiene 4 años ofreciendo a su clientela una buena atención, un mejor servicio y variedad de estilos de ropa. Desde que comenzó su negocio vio que daba resultados por lo que siguió adelante ya que seria la forma de tener un ingreso extra aparte del que percibía en la maquiladora. José Luis desea comprar ropa de temporada de tiempo de frio, por que en este momento ya sus clientes le están solicitando y ve que es una buena oportunidad de tener mayores ganancias.
texts.en:
Señor José Luis and his wife are enterprising people who enjoy working.  For this reason, they decided to sell used clothes in one of the city neighborhoods, and this has allowed them to develop into good business-people.  They have been tending well to their customers through this business for four years now, offering good service and a variety of clothing styles.

Since he began this business, he has seen it provide results that kept him moving forward.  It has also been an additional source of income to what he earns at the factory.

José Luis wants to buy seasonal clothes for the cold weather, because his customers are already starting to look for them at this time and he sees it as a good opportunity to bring in better earnings.

loans.use: to buy seasonal clothing for his business.

loans.name: Janeth

texts.en:
Janeth is married and has three children. She is 33 years old and two of her children are in school.

Janeth has a food vending business in the Philippines. She is a very hard working entrepreneur. Janeth has requested a PHP 20,000 loan amount through NWTF to buy ingredients for her food business.

Janeth has been in this business for 20 years. In the future, Janeth would like to save enough money to expand her business.

loans.use: to buy ingredients for her food production business.

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: To buy kitchen utensils and supplies

loans.name: Amos

texts.en: Amos is a thirty-eight-year-old married man with three children living in a semi-permanent house in Fort Portal, Uganda. His family dream is educating his children and owning at least five motorcycles. He has been operating a retail shop and a motorcycle business for the last eight years. He faces challenges with high fuel costs. Amos needs the loan to buy another motorcycle so that he can increase his income.

loans.use: to buy another motorcycle.

loans.name: Cristobal Javier

texts.es:
Cristóbal, está interesado por un nuevo préstamo, para completar el valor de un vehículo pick up, para transportar el pan, por las zonas donde tiene clientes, esta compra de trasporte le ayudara para abastecer a un mayor número de zonas y clientes.
La condición de Cristóbal ha mejorado, debido al aumento en sus ventas y ganancias.
texts.en: Christopher is interested in a new loan, which will be used to pay off the loan on his pickup truck. This truck will be used to transport bread to areas where he has customers. This transportation will help him to supply his bread to a larger area and more customers. Christopher’s situation has improved. This loan will increase his sales and earnings.

loans.use: to pay off the loan on his vehicle.

loans.name: Rosa Ivania

texts.es: Rosa emprendedora, trabajadora desde hace un tiempo tiene su propio negocio venta de variedades. Junto a su esposo han ido realizándole mejoras a su vivienda ya que sus planes es tener completamente de concreto la infraestructura. El préstamo anterior fue de gran beneficio ya que cumplió con los pedidos de su clientela. Para este nuevo ciclo de préstamo tiene proyectado vender más para invertir en su vivienda he comodidad de sus hijos. Comprara productos como: ropa de damas, caballeros, niños, zapatos, cosméticos, bisutería, perfumes, lociones para caballeros, desodorantes, pantalones, ropas interiores entre otros productos que para en este tiempo de fiesta navideña son buscadas en mayores cantidades por sus clientes. Agradece a la financiera por el apoyo al desarrollo de su negocio.
texts.en:
Rosa is an enterprising, hardworking woman. For some time she has had her own business selling a range of items. Together with her husband she has carried out some improvements on their home. Their plan is to have its structure completely concreted. 

The previous loan was very beneficial and Rosa completed her customers' orders. Her plan for this new loan cycle is to sell more, in order to invest in her home and her children's wellbeing. She will buy products including women's, men's and children's clothing, shoes, cosmetics, costume jewellery, perfume, men's grooming products, deodorant, trousers and underwear among other products. At Christmas time her customers look for items like these in larger quantities. 

She is grateful to the financing organisation for helping her business to grow.

loans.use: to buy  women's, men's and children's clothing, shoes, cosmetics, costume jewellery, perfume, men's grooming products, deodorant, trousers and underwear.

loans.name: Juana

texts.es:
La socia Juana se sigue dedicando al negocio de venta de golosinas,ella tiene una carreta donde vende chupetes,caramelos,galletas y gaseosas,ella tiene su carreta en forma ambulatoria,la socia trabaja desde las 8:00 a.m hasta las 6:00 p.m,por medio de este negocio la socia saca adelante a sus hijos,la socia quiere ampliar y mejorar el negocio de venta de golosinas.La socia solicita el credito para comprar galletas,caramelos,chupetes y gaseosas al por mayor.

La socia está feliz por el préstamo y se compromete a cumplir con los pagos de su cuota.
texts.en:
Juana continues in her business selling sweets.  She has a cart where she sells lollipops, candies, cookies and soda.  She works with her little cart as an itinerant street vendor.  She works from 8.00am to 6.00pm and, through this business, she provides for her children.  Juana would like to expand and improve her business selling sweets.  She is requesting this loan to buy cookies, candies, lollipops and soda wholesale. 

Juana is happy to be receiving her loan and pledges to make her repayments on time.

loans.use: to buy cookies, candies, lollipops and soda wholesale

loans.name: Janeth

texts.en:
Janeth is 38 years old and lives in the Philippines. She is married with five children. 
Janeth has a shop that sells canned goods, snacks and beverages. She has run this business for five years. She has requested a loan of 10,000 PHP to buy canned goods, snacks and beverages.
Janeth has been a member of Kiva partner HSPFI since 2011. In the future, she hopes to improve her business.

loans.use: to buy canned goods, snacks and beverages.

loans.name: Evangeline

texts.en:
Evangeline is a hardworking entrepreneur who has operated a fishing business in the Philippines for 16 years. She is borrowing PHP 22,000 through NWTF to buy more bamboo and fishing net for her business. Evangeline earns additional income from clothing sales.

Evangeline has been sustaining her business activities through her own efforts with the help of loans from NWTF. She dreams of saving money to expand her business in the future.

loans.use: to buy more bamboo and fishing net .

loans.name: Vivian

texts.en:
This is Vivian, 52, a resident of Bacoor, Cavite City, Philippines. She is a widow and mother of two children. Together with her children, she manages the household while operating a business. At this time, she is working hard to continually provide income for the family's everyday expenses and her children’s studies. 
Vivian maintains a direct selling business. She sells clothing, footwear, undergarments, cosmetics and other products through popular direct sales brands such as Avon, Fullerlife, Natasha, Boardwalk, Marikina Shoe Exchange, and other direct selling brands. A customer's order is bought in cash by the dealer and then given to the customer with one-month-to-pay credit. Dealer’s prices are lower than those in the catalogue, and these are the profits that dealers are investing on as their income. Vivian's regular customers are her neighbours and members of the local community. She earns a minimum of 1,500 Philippine Pesos (PHP) in sales every week.
To help Vivian continue to operate her business, she is requesting a loan of 10,000 PHP. She will use the loan to buy merchandise and orders for her customers. She expects a boost in her business income as she expands her business.  
Vivian fervently hopes that her children will be able to graduate one day. She faithfully meets up with her co-fellowship members to share stories of her work every week and to draw strength and inspiration from the Word of God she studies.

* All CCT community partners / clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and pay microfinance loans.

loans.use: to buy merchandise for her business.

loans.name: Lorna

texts.en:
Lorna is 45 years old and lives in the Philippines. She is married with three children. 

Lorna has a food shop, or "sari-sari" store, that sells canned goods, snacks, and beverages. She has had this business for 10 years. She requested a loan for 10,000 Philippine pesos (PHP) to buy canned goods, snacks, and beverages.

Lorna has been a member of HSPFI since 2011. In the future, Lorna hopes to improve her business.

loans.use: to buy canned goods, snacks, and beverages

loans.name: Falada Group

texts.fr:
Composé majoritairement  de femmes mariées, les 4 membres du groupe    FALADA, vivent dans des familles polygames  avec en moyenne 25 ans et 2 enfants. Elles habitent toutes dans la ville de Kolondièba et se sont connues à travers des liens de voisinage, de parenté et de mariage. Elles font l’achat et la vente des poissons, fumé, séché et des produits céréaliers. 
Dans le but d’augmenter leurs fonds de commerce, les membres du groupe  intègrent  Soro Yiriwaso  et sont à leur 1er prêt solidaire.
Oumou, qui est la femme assise, est la vendeuse de poissons séché du groupe. Elle compte utiliser son prêt pour acheter, 10 kilos de poisson séché auprès des forains fréquentant la foire hebdomadaire de Kolondièba. Elle effectue sa vente au comptant, en détail et à crédit à une clientèle composée de femmes et d’hommes. Avec ce prêt, Madame Oumou espère réaliser un bénéfice mensuel moyen de 12.500 FCFA qui sera utilisé pour être réinvesti dans l’activité et prendre en charge  certains besoins du foyer.
texts.en:
Mainly married women, the four members of the FALADA group live in polygamous families, are on average 25 years old and have an average of two children. They all live in the city of Kolondièba and know each other through their neighborhood ties, relatives, and through marriage. They are in the business of buying and selling smoked and dried fish, as well as grain products. In order to increase their working capital, the group members are partnering with Soro Yiriwaso for their first group loan. 

Oumou, the woman seated in the picture, is the group member who sells dried fish. She plans to use her loan to buy ten kilos of dried fish from vendors at the weekly market in Kolondièba.   She conducts her sales in cash and on credit to both male and female customers. With this loan, Oumou hopes to achieve an average monthly profit of 12,500 francs CFA, which will be used to reinvest in the business and take care of some household needs.

loans.use: to buy fish to resell.

loans.name: Ibrahim

texts.en: Salahim is a versatile trader. She sells assorted cooked foods. These includes boiled rice and beans popularly called \"wakye\" for members of the community she stays. Though she is a Muslim by religion she does not allow this to serve as a hindrance in her trading activity. She sells her cooked food to Muslims and other members of different religious sect without discrimination. She enjoys a lot of patronage from all persons living within her community due to her humourous nature. She needs a KIVA loan amount of $800 to plough into her business operations. She has participated in the TEACH lending programs.

loans.use: Working capital

loans.name: Simon

texts.en:
Despite his old age, Simon is still a hardworking rice farmer. He has lived in Santa Lucia his entire life, in fact the lands he owns were given to him by his father. For over 50 years Simon has been making ends meet with the rice that his lands produce. He and his wife Victoria have relied on their farm to raise there 3 children who are all adults now. Simon is requesting the loan because he wants to avoid having to borrow from loan sharks in order to buy his supplies. He has been using those informal loans for most of his time in Santa Lucia and he is optimistic about the presence of formal finance.

The Paypayales Communal Bank in Santa Lucia

Simon is part of one of the newest Communal Banks in the recently developed Mifex Rural Finance Program: the Paypayales Communal Bank. All bank members are part of a rice farmers' cooperative in Santa Lucia named Dios Con Nosotros (God is with us). They will use these microloans to prepare their lands and cultivate rice on their farms. As members of a communal bank, they are all the guarantors for each other's loans. This means that if for some reason one person in the group cannot fully repay the loan, the other borrowers and the Dios con Nosotros Cooperative are responsible for the amount in default. The members of the bank also participate in a program designed to teach and encourage savings among the group. Promoting savings is often forgotten in many microfinance programs, but Mifex believes that is imperative for the communities we works with to have capital reserved for future investments or unexpected difficulties.

Below is more information about the commnity of Santa Lucia, compiled by Luis Crespo and Robert Edgar of the Mifex team when evaluating the potential of the sector for the Rural Finance Program. Special thanks to Mario Balazantegui who provided expert insight and contributed to the development of the alliances with the local organizations.

Economy of Santa Lucia

Santa Lucia County has a population of about 33,000 people. The region is fit for rice cultivating because it is not in the lowlands and therefore it is not at risk of flooding. There is also great access to water because of the Daule River, which is accessible to many of the farmers in the area. About 70% of the farmers have basic infrastructure for watering their crops.

Rice production is the main economic activity of the area, as about 80% of the people are rice farmers. Almost everyone is either directly or indirectly involved with the rice production, as they produce, commercialize or participate in activities that add value to the product. Within the county, there is a small town also named Santa Lucia. The town is filled with many small businesses and it serves as the social and commercial hub of the area.

Rice Farming in Santa Lucia

Most of the people in the Santa Lucia area are small farmers. They produce about 100 sacks of rice per hectare of land. In order to farm they first must prepare the lands by removing weeds and plowing. The farmers then fill an area with water to form what is known as a paddy field, because rice is a very water intensive crop. The rice seeds are either dispersed freely (the process is known as boleo in Spanish) or hand sowed. Once the rice has grown, most farmers rent machinery that helps them harvest their crop. A risk factor does exist in rice farming because of drought, but in Santa Lucia this is somewhat mitigated by the access to water form the nearby river.

Access to Credit

The biggest struggle in the area has been the lack of credit. Because people do not have access to formal financial services, they have turned to loan sharks for financing. They have been affected by expensive lines of credit that exceed 100% interest a year and can be as expensive as 240%. Intermediaries also exploit the farmers because of their outstanding debt. Farmers also often lack skills and knowledge of how to commercialize their product and get fair prices for their crops.

Loan Use

The loans in this sector will be used to to buy soil, seeds, fertilizer and insecticides. They will also be used to prepare the land prior to farming, to plant the seeds and purchase other materials. The loan repayment schedule is different from the typical microentrepreneur. Because farmers see the profits from their investments 5 or 6 months after making their initial expenditures, Mifex asks them to repay 50% of the capital in the first 6 months of the loan. The rest of the debt must be paid in the seventh and final month.

loans.use: Farm Rice

loans.name: Maqasd

texts.en: Maqasd A. is an Internally Displaced Person from the Dacqin region of Azerbaijan. He resettled in the Aghsu region 10 years with his wife, where he tried to support himself and his family by opening up a small electronic repair shop. It has been hard for him and his family losing everything when they fled from their home. Maqasd repairs in his shop televisions, computers and other household appliances. He is requesting his first loan of $500 from Normicro in order to purchase some much needed tools and supplies for his shop.

loans.use: To purchase equipment and tools for use in his electronic repair shop

loans.name: Lea Nellely

texts.es:
Lea is very hard-working and responsible. She is married, has five children between 1 and 11 years old, and her husband works as a taxi driver. This means he hasn't had a secure income to help with the home and children's expenses for three years. Lea is working with used clothing sales, and little by little has grown her client base, and her sales, considerably.

To be able to meet her customers' demand, Lea is requesting a loan of $250 which she will use to purchase merchandise, with which she hopes to have better variety and offer a good service. She is committed to returning this amount in 3 months. Lea and her family thank you very much for your confidence and support.

Translated from Spanish by a Kiva volunteer.

Lea es muy trabajadora y responsable, está casada y tiene cinco hijos entre 1 y 11 años D. edad, su esposo se desempeña como taxista por lo que no cuenta con un ingreso seguro, para ayudar con los gastos del hogar y sacar adelante a sus hijos desD. hace tres años Lea se dedica a L. venta D. ropa usada, poco a poco fueron incrementando sus clientes y sus ventas considerablemente.

Para poder cubrir L. demanda D. sus clientes Lea solicita un préstamo D. $ 250 dólares que empleará en L. compra D. mercancía, con lo que espera tener una mejor variedad y ofrecer un buen servicio, elL. se compromete a regresar esta cantidad en 3 meses. Lea y su familia agradecen mucho tu confianza y apoyo.

loans.use: Compra de mercancía

loans.name: Auteletoa

texts.en: Auteletoa is a married woman of 28 years of age. They have had their shop for a long time, and she decided to join SPBD. Her intention is to buy more goods for her shop, because this is the only shop in this area. Auteletoa's shop used to be run by her mother, but unfortunately she's very old and it was hard for her to look after the shop day and night. Auteletoa's first loan she used to buy many things to fill the shelves, and with the help of her husband she managed to grow their business. In the future, Auteletoa is planning to expand the size of her shop and to increase the amount of goods sold each day.

loans.use: To assist with her business

loans.name: Garyaghdi

texts.en: Garyaghdi is 44 years old.  He is a refugee from the Lachin region situated in the east part of Azerbaijan, which is now part of the Azerbaijan-Armenian conflict zone.  He and his family were relocated to Baku in 1991.  At that time he started to work as a taxi driver with his own car to earn income for his family of his wife and two children.  He works inside the town and sometimes goes long distances to other regions.  He now wants to buy new tires for his car.  As he has little of his own funds to do this, he has applied to Normicro Baku branch to borrow $600 to buy new tires and to do some repairs as well. This is his first loan from Normicro.

loans.use: To repair his taxi and buy new tires

loans.name: Wilmer

texts.es:
Wilmer lives in his own home with his wife and son on May 27 Avenue in Periférica in the city of La Paz. He works at a financial institution and the loan he's requesting is to buy a computer to be able to realize his accounting jobs, since he is studying to better himself and to be able to increase his income.

He doesn't have a credit with Impro but qualifies to receive one.

Translated from Spanish by Tanya Harper, Kiva volunteer

Wilmer vive en casa propia con su esposa e hijo en la av. 27 de mayo de la zona Periférica de la ciudad de La Paz; trabaja como empleado en una institución financiera y el crédito que solicita es para comprar una computadora y así poder realizar sus trabajos de contabilidad ya que esta estudiando por que desea superarse y poder aumentar sus ingresos.

No tiene crédito con Impro pero califica para acceder a un crédito.

loans.use: Purchase of a computer for his accounting studies

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To buy more food Items for cooking and selling

loans.name: Rano

texts.en:
Rano C. is 40 years old. She is married with three children of school age.

Five years ago Rano decided to start her own business for the purpose of  improving the economic position of the family. Rano is selling shoes for kids in the local market. The husband of Rano was unemployed for a long time and not so recently he left for Russia to earn some money. Because of that, Rano’s business currently is the main source of income for supporting  her family. 

The spring is coming soon, and Rano will have to purchase  shoes for kids for the spring season. With this purpose she requests a loan of $600.00 US Dollars for the term of 10 months. Rano thanks all for their support and promises to pay the loan on time.

loans.use: Purchasing of  shoes for kids for the spring season for selling.

loans.name: Kay

texts.en:
Mrs. Kay P., 31, sells grocery products and beef, earning approximately three dollars a day. Her husband sells natural medicine from province to province and earns, on average, five dollars a day. The couple has four children, all of whom are students.

This loan will be used to purchase a market stand in a busy market.

loans.use: This loan will be used to purchase a market stand in a busy market.

loans.name: Florence Nakato’S Group

texts.en:
Florence is 46 years old and is the group leader of 5 people. This is the first loan for the entire group. They know each other very well and live in the same neighborhood, so they trust each other with this venture. Florence has 5 children, ages 17 to 23 years old. All of them are in school right now, but at times they have not been able to attend due to the cost of school fees.

Florence’s business is selling charcoal. She has been selling charcoal in her neighborhood for the past six years. One challenge Florence faces with selling charcoal is that the wholesale price changes frequently due to the weather. For example, when it rains the price goes up because the rain affects the road, which causes the transport fees to increase. This loan will help Florence because she no longer has to try to get a loan from the bank, which can be very difficult. She also hopes to be able to pay for school fees consistently and provide more food for her family. She hopes to expand her business and, one day, open another store.

loans.use: To buy charcoal

loans.name: Ni Ketut

texts.id:
The price of cooking oil has gone up, but that has not stopped Ni Ketut from continuing her business selling chicken-foot krupuk (a snack made of fried chicken feet). Every morning at 5AM Ni Ketut, who lives on Raya Sading Street, goes to Sempidi Market to purchase chicken feet. After returning to her house she boils the chicken feet for an hour. After they cool she removes the skin and bones and lets them sit. Once they are dry, she fries them and packages them up. By the late afternoon the krupuk are ready for selling to small restaurants in the area. Ni Ketut uses the profits from her business to pay for her children to go to school and to to pay for the day-to-day needs of her family.

Translated from Bahasa Indonesia by Courtenay Teska Race, Kiva Volunteer.

Meskipun harga minyak goreng terus naik, tapi itu tidak menyurutkan niat Ni Ketut untuk terus menekuni usaha jualan krupuk ayam. Setiap hari, Ni Ketut, yang bertempat tinggal di Jl.Raya Sading, kira-kira pukul 05.00 pagi berangkat ke Pasar Sempidi untuk membeli ceker ayam. Stelah tiba dirumah, kemudian ceker itu direbus selama 1 jam lalu ditiriskan. Setelah dingin, ceker ayam dipisahkan dari tulang dan kulit, lalu kemudian dijemur. Setelah kering lalu digoreng dan dibungkus. Pada sore harinya krupuk ceker siap untuk diantar ke warung-warung diseputaran sading. Dai usaha ini ia bisa membiayai sekolah kedua anaknya dan juga untuk biaya hidup sehari-hari.

loans.use: To increase funding for her business

loans.name: Jamila

texts.en: R. Jamila is 33 years old and has 2 children. Her husband is a cook in a local restaurant. In order to help her husband support the family, Jamila is running her own business. She sells clothes and shoes for children in a rented store that is located in her home town. In addition, each Friday, Jamila sells clothes and shoes in a market in the neighboring city. Those days she works from 5 a.m. until late evening. Jamila's husband helps her run the sales business on Fridays. Currently, Jamila is planning to increase the store inventory by purchasing more goods for the summer season. Therefore, she is asking for a loan of US$500 for a 6-month term. Having proved herself as an honest and reliable client of her loan organization, Jamila promises to repay also the current loan on time. Jamila is thankful to everyone who has supported her thus far, allowing her to develop her business.

loans.use: Purchase of new children's clothes and shoes for the summer season

loans.name: Rose Namubiru's Group

texts.en:
Rose is the leader of a 5-member group. She is 50 years old and married with 8 children between 30 and 12 years of age. Six of them are in school. The community she resides in and works in is semi-urban, within a slum and low-lying area that is vulnerable to floods.

Rose has been operating her small food shop for 20 years. She sells her food mostly to families that live in the area. Rose’s main challenges are the thieves in the area and stiff competition.

Rose plans to use this loan to buy sugar, salt, rice and maize flour. By increasing her stock, Rose hopes to keep her customers coming back. In addition, buying these raw materials in bulk will decrease her transportation costs.

Through her loans and the profits from her business, Rose has been able to contribute to the running of the home and to paying the school fees of her children.

Rose has successfully paid back more than 20 loans since working with MCDT. She hopes one day she can afford to build a house and buy a big refrigerator.

loans.use: Increase stock

loans.name: Koemsroeng

texts.en:
Mrs. Koemsroeng L. is a villager in Duem Pring village in the Kandal province. She is farmer and grocer. Some of her customers use credit to buy groceries. As a result, Mrs. Koemsroeng L. does not have enough money to invest in her business. Thus, she decided to ask for a loan to buy more grocery goods in order to expand her current business.

Mrs. Koemsroeng L. is a widow with two children. One of her children is employed in a garment factory and the other is a construction worker.

loans.use: To buy more grocery goods in order to expand her current business.

loans.name: Hosn

texts.en:
Hosn lives in Burj Barajneh, a suburban area of Beirut where, as a mother of five children, she started tailoring as a hobby. When her husband lost his job during the civil war, she decided to offer her tailoring services to customers while at home. In 2000, she received her first micro loan to buy a sewing machine, the first of several improvements in both her business and family life.  Over the years as she expanded her activity, Hosn managed to help her husband buy a car to work as a taxi driver and send her children to school. 

"Oum Walid", as everybody calls her, possesses a welcoming smile that has made her well known in the neighborhood. Today, she wishes to expand her home-based business and plans to use this new loan to buy inventory and perhaps rent a small shop that would make her more accessible to her clients.

loans.use: To buy goods for her business

loans.name: Fidela

texts.es: Fidela tiene 42 años, es madre de un hijo, que es su razón de salir adelante y a quien le demuestra sus ganas de superación. Es propietaria de 2 motocarros que los hace trabajar en transporte de pasajeros.Adicionalmente, trabaja como secretaria en una empresa de su localidad, sin embargo, su deseo es comprar repuestos y mandar a refaccionar sus motocarros para que trabajen mejor y produzcan mejores ingresos, posteriormente le gustaría tener un taller de motos y lubricentro, por lo que requiere de la cantidad de dinero que solicita, promete ser puntual en sus pagos.
texts.en:
Fidela is 42 years old, mother of one son who is her reason to be successful and to whom she demonstrates her desire to succeed. She is the owner of 2 motorcars that work to transport passengers. In addition, she works as a secretary in a neighborhood business, nevertheless, her wish is to buy parts and send her motorcars for repair so that they work better and produce greater income. Later she would like to have a repair shop and lube center, so she requires the loan she seeks and promises to be punctual with her payments.

Translated from Spanish by Cindy Kendall, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buy parts to repair her motorcars

loans.name: Elsa

texts.es:
La señora Elsa pertenece al Banco Comunal “Sol Naciente”, ubicado en el Jr. 28 Guillermo Sisley Nº 735, distrito de Callería, provincia de Coronel Portillo, departamento de Ucayali. Tiene 54 años de edad, es madre de 5 hijos mayores de edad, es casada y su esposo es jubilado de la carrera de Medicina. Con el primer préstamo que recibió de Manuela Ramos de S/. 300 decide invertir en la venta ce comida y gaseosa. Viene trabajando hace años con Manuela Ramos.

En la actualidad cuenta con un pequeño restaurante en casa. Se levanta a las 5am para ir al mercado y luego preparar sus deliciosos platos para vender y brindar una buena atención a sus clientes.

Con este préstamo de S/. 1,000, el cual será pagado en 4 meses, comprará 20 kilos de arroz, 3 litros de aceite, 6 pollos, 6 kilos de carne, 5 kilos de pescado, verduras, etc. 

Elsa expresa alegría en su rostro porque su negocio ha mejorado y sus clientes van más seguido a su restaurante y a la vez le dan la oportunidad de seguir surgiendo en la vida.
texts.en:
Elsa is a member of the community bank "Sol Naciente", located in Jr. 28 Guillermo Sisley No. 735, in the district of Calleria within the province of Coronle Portillo in Ucayali. She is 54 yeras old and she is mother of 5 children, all of whom are of age. She is married and her husband is retired from a career in medicine. With the first loan she received from Manuela Ramos, amounting to S/.300, she decided to invest in the food and soft drink sales. She has been working many years with Manuela Ramos.

Currently she runs a small restaurant from her home. She wakes up at 5 a.m. to go to the market and then prepaper her delicious cooking to sell and provide good service to her clients.

With this loan, amounting to S/.1000 for a term of 4 months, she will purchase 20 kg of rice, 3 litres of cooking oil, 6 chicken, 6 kg of meat, 5 kg of fish, vegetables, etc.

You can see happiness in Elsa's face because her business has improved and her clients come back more often to her restaurant, and at the same time they give her the opportunity to keep succeeding in life.


Translated from Spanish by Erika Lindig, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To purchase rice, cooking oil, meat, fish, vegetables, etc.

loans.name: Martha Lorena

texts.es:
La microempresaria Marta Lorena B. tiene 51 años de edad es casada con cinco hijos los cuales estudian en nivel primario y secundario. Esta señora se dedica desde hace 10 años a administrar una pulpería en donde vende una variedad de productos, tanto carne de res, granos básicos y otros.

Con este negocio ha podido tener ingresos para poder mantener su hogar ya que cuenta con una buena clientela, sin embargo el local no cuenta con suficiente seguridad por lo que ya en una ocasión fue victima de robo. Para evitar que vuelva a ser víctima de robo debe hacer una inversión de instalar verjas de hierro, pero esta inversión la descapitalizaría y no podría comprar mas productos.

Por tal motivo necesita el financiamiento para la construcción de dos verjas de hierro para las dos ventanas del local y cada una de estas le cuesta US$ 50 dólares cada una mas la mano de obra valorada en US$ 95 dólares y además comprar una vitrina para poder exhibir sus productos la cual le cuesta US$100 dólares.
texts.en:
Businesswoman Marta Lorena B. is 51 years old and married with five children who attend either primary or secondary school. For the last 10 years Martha has run a small store where she sells a variety of products such as beef, grains etc. The business has provided her with sufficient income to pay her household expenses, and she also has loyal customer base. However, the area now feels unsafe as she was on one occasion the victim of a robbery. So that this doesn’t happen again, she wants to invest in some metal security bars. Such an investment would mean that she wouldn’t have sufficient capital to buy more products for her store. For this reason she needs a loan in order to install security bars on two windows, each of which will cost US$50. On top of that is the cost of installation, about US$95. In addition she wants to buy a glass cabinet in which to display her products, a further cost of US$100.

Translated from Spanish by Jane Agg, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: to buy a display cabinet and installation of security bars on two windows

loans.name: Irene

texts.es: Irene tiene 31 años, vive con su esposo y sus 2 hijos. Se dedica al transporte, junto a su esposo poseen movilidades que cubren la ruta de Jauja a Huancayo (1 hora y media), esta actividad es la que les permite tener ingresos en la familia, Irene se encarga de administrar y controlar que sus carros siempre estén en sus rutas, además siempre está al pendiente del correcto funcionamiento de sus movilidades, es por ello que tiene un depósito de repuestos de llantas y otros implementos para auto. Irene se siente satisfecha por su negocio y tiene muchos deseos de continuar dedicándose al transporte, ya que ella lo ve con mucho futuro por delante. Es su 4to préstamo con MFP, es una clienta de confianza. Con el dinero que solicita podrá invertir en el mantenimiento y la revisión mecánica de sus movilidades.
texts.en:
Irene is 31 years old and lives with her husband and their two children. She is dedicated to transportation, and together with her husband they possess vehicles that cover the route from Jauja to Huancayo (one and a half hours). This activity is what allows the family to have an income. Irene is in charge of managing their cars so that they are always on their routes and so she is always dependent on them running properly, which is why she has a warehouse of replacement tires and other car parts. Irene feels satisfied by her business and has a lot of desire to continue working in transportation, since she sees in it a good future ahead. This is her fourth loan with MFP and she is a trustworthy client. With the money that she is requesting, she will be able to invest in the maintenance and the mechanic repairs of her vehicles.

Translated from Spanish by Jay Osborne, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Maintenance of her cars.

loans.name: Wakulima Group

texts.en:
Kidawa Issa S., age 45, is married with two children, ages 15 and 7. She has a business selling vegetables, chicken, and fabrics. She started her businesses about 15 years ago and works daily from 6am until 8pm. She is able to earn a monthly profit of about US$ 74.

This will be Kidawa’s 1st loan from Tujijenge Tanzania. She will use this loan to increase her stocks of all her inventory.

Kidawa will share this loan with subgroup A of the Wakulima group. The subgroup has 7 members who run shops, sell charcoal, clothes, vegetables, fruits, TV and radios. These members hold each other accountable in paying back their loans. In the picture, Kidawa is 1st from right, in the back, covering her head in dark brown.

loans.use: To expand her business inventory

loans.name: Champ De Victoire Group

texts.en:
Charles sells salted fish imported from Angola. He started his first business running a telephone booth and selling beverages outdoors in 2000. His beginning capital was US$ 250. With hard work and determination, his business prospered and in 2004 he was able to rent a place for his business and move it indoors.

In 2005, that building was sold by the owner and Charles had to move out and look for another place to do business. Unfortunately, his new place was located in an area where he was not known. So, he had to start building up a new customer base. As Charles’ goods did not match the needs he saw in that area, he changed his business and became a salted fish seller.

Charles is now well-known and liked in this new area. He has been with Hope DRCongo since 2007. Since that time, his business has prospered, and the loans he has received have helped him rent a well-located business place. He makes about US$ 80 in profit each week. His working capital is US$ 600.

Charles is 42 years old, married, and the father of four children, aged between 1 and 17 of whom two go to school. His ambition is to become a salted fish wholesaler in his new area.

loans.use: To rent a place and move his business indoors in order to avoid the heavy rain and the strong sun

loans.name: Graciela

texts.es: Graciela de 24 años de edad, vive con su esposo y su pequeña hija. La casa donde viven es propia. Ella se dedica a vender repuestos de celulares, como también vende recargas virtuales y físicas para estos teléfonos, esta actividad la viene haciendo desde hace un año. Ella trabaja junto con su esposo quien es el encargado de reparar algunos equipos celulares malogrados (técnico de teléfonos). Lo que le gusta de su trabajo es conocer muchas personas, además le es rentable porque trabaja junto con su esposo y ambos ven que sus ingresos son buenos. Posteriormente quiere alquilar un local para instalara unas cabinas telefónicas. Este es su 4to su crédito con MFP, y con el dinero solicitado quiere comprar más repuestos para celulares para lo cual gastará toda la cantidad requerida.
texts.en:
Graciela is 24 years old and lives with her husband and small daughter. The house she lives in is her own. She sells cell phone covers, chargers, and other phone accessories. She has been doing this trade for a year. She works with her husband who is the manager of repairing broken cell phones. She likes her job because she meets a lot of people and it is profitable because she works with her husband, both of whom earn good income. In the future, she wants to rent a shop to display the phones. This loan with be her fourth with MFP and she will spend the entirety of the loan on more cell phone covers.

Translated from Spanish by Brittany Thatcher, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase cell phone covers for resale

loans.name: Bibisora

texts.en:
M. Bibisora is a hard working woman. Since 1998 she has dedicated herself to selling a variety of vegetables in the central market of Tursunzade. She characterizes herself as happy and humble. She started her business with her savings which she had accumulated over a long period of time. She is the mother of two minor children to whom she would like to offer an education. To realize this dream, Bibisora now requests 2500 Somoni for the term of 10 months. With this loan she wants to buy a greater variety of vegetables to increase her earnings. With your collaboration she’ll be able to realize her dream in a short time.   


More about Tajikistan and IMON International

Tajikistan is perhaps best known for its rich history, which includes a key post along the Silk Road; the end of Alexander the Great's rule; and with it’s famous great thinkers, philosophers, scientists and poets as: Rudaki, Ibn Sina (Avicenna), Firdousi, Omar Haiyam, Jomi, Mavlavi Rumi and many others. The country is home to communities that still speak the ancient Sogdian language, epic mountain passes, and a civilization that dates back to the 4th millennium BC.  And, even today, it is a complex mixture of the Islamic faith, Soviet culture, New West culture and Central Asian traditions. 
But, Tajikistan is also the poorest of the former Soviet republics.  The civil war, which ignited soon after its independence from the U.S.S.R., further damaged the already weak economy.  In addition, 93% of the country is mountainous and only 7% of the land is arable.  These conditions have resulted in high levels of unemployment and have forced hundreds of thousands to seek work in other countries, mainly Russia.  While the people of Tajikistan are working to improve its agricultural production and manufacturing sector, nearly two-thirds of the population still live in abject poverty. 

IMON's History
Since December 2007, IMON International has worked closely with Kiva and Kiva lenders to ensure that poor and low income clients represent a viable business proposition. Funds raised through Kiva have already been distributed to thousands of IMON International's clients and will continue to provide thousands more with permanent access to the varied financial services they need. To learn more about IMON International's work, please visit: www.imon.tj

loans.use: To increase the the variety of vegetables she sells

loans.name: Leila

texts.en:
Leila is a 43-year-old married woman with one child living in Rachaya in Bekaa valley. She has owned a clothing shop called "Leila’s Shop" since 2002.

Today, Leila wants to borrow $1,200 to increase her inventory in order to develop her shop.

loans.use: To increase her inventory

loans.name: Pacita

texts.en:
Pacita P. is a resident of Sepac, Sapang Dalaga, Misamis Occidental. She has been a good member of Paglaum Cooperative for almost four years and obtaining a loan helps her a lot in her daily needs. It also helps her to send her children to school.

This, her sixth loan cycle, amounts to Php 6,500, and is intended for corn production. It is her dream to buy fertilizers for her corn plantation for a good harvest.

She's is also thankful to Paglaum micro-finance for their programs and services that help the poor people and encourages them to work hard for their future. They wish to have a better living in the future and be able to give their children a good future.

loans.use: To buy fertilizers for her corn plantation

loans.name: Nguyen Thi

texts.en:
Tuyết Nguyễn Thị, 50 years old, lives in the town of Quảng Xương. She is married and has six adult-aged children. Tuyết earns a living by owning and operating a business venture in the agriculture sector raising livestock. The main source of income for the business comes primarily from raising pigs for sale. Tuyết has just started operating this business and earns approximately 700,000 VND a month from these activities.

In 2006, Tuyết joined TYM Fund in order to gain access to financial services so that she can help improve her living situation and increase her ability to engage in business activities. Tuyết has successfully repaid a previous loan of 9,000,000 VND from TYM Fund. This previous loan was used to purchase breeding livestock.

Tuyết is now requesting a new loan of 9,000,000 VND, which will be used to purchase baby livestock to raise and sell in the future. This will be the fourth loan taken out by this borrower from TYM Fund. Tuyết plans to use the additional revenue she expects to be generated from the business to improve and expand her business ventures.

loans.use: To purchase baby livestock to raise and sell in future

loans.name: Maria Bernarda

texts.es: María Bernarda R. Gracia tiene 73 años de edad. Es madre soltera. Y tiene 5 hijos a su cargo y todos estudian. La actividad económica es una pulpería. Hace más de 21 años que se dedica a este negocio. Doña María decidió iniciar este negocio por la necesidad de buscar el sustento diario para sus hijos por lo que ella, siempre ha sido una mujer muy responsable además fue madre y padre para sus hijos. Por lo que los financiamientos le han permitido comprar lo necesario para su negocio y comprar mayores cantidades de productos. El dinero que solicita es para capital de trabajo en la compra de granos básicos, golosinas, refrescos naturales. Su deseo es mejorar las condiciones de su vivienda.
texts.en:
Maria Bernarda R. Gracia, 73, is a single mother. She supports 5 children, all in school. She operates a small general store, a business that she's had for more than 21 years. Dona Maria decided to start the business because she needed to find a way to support her children. She's always been a very responsible woman and someone who has had to be both mother and father to her children. The loans have allowed her to buy what she needs for the business and wholesale supplies of the products she sells. The money that she wants to borrow will be used as working capital to buy basic grains, snacks and natural drinks. Her greatest hope is to make improvements to her house.

Translated from Spanish by Jere Wiseman, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Working capital.

loans.name: Pacencio

texts.en:
Pacencio S. wants to put up a mini variety store in his village to cater to all the needs of his fellow villagers. He is from the village of Lumbia, Cagayan de Oro City. Pacencio is 55 years old, married and has four adult children.

In 2009, Pacencio joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve his living conditions and enable him to engage in business activities. Pacencio is requesting a loan of 5000 PHP which will be used to purchase products to sell. This will be his first loan from HSPFI. He plans to use the additional revenue to supplement the income of his family.

About HSPFI: HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional products to sell

location.town: Lumbia, Cagayan de Oro, Misamis Oriental

loans.name: Helman Santiago

texts.es: El señor Helman Santiago R. López, tiene la edad de 30 años, habita en el barrio Lomas del Gavilán, ubicado en Masaya, junto a su esposa la cual le apoya con los gastos del hogar, ellos tienen dos hijos, la niña de siete años estudia actualmente y el varón de tres años, los planes hacia su familia es mejorar las condiciones de vida, don Helman desde hace cinco años se dedica a la agricultura , la mayor dificultad que se le presenta es la falta de asesoramiento técnico , ya que por no saber inducir bien los fertilizantes a perdido producción , el inicio esta actividad con sus propios esfuerzos , los planes futuros hacia su cultivo es poder tener una buena producción. Con el préstamo va a comprar fertilizantes y poder lograr una buena producción.
texts.en:
Helman R. López is 30 years old and lives with his wife in the Lomas del Gavilán neighborhood, located in Masaya. She helps him with household tasks. They have two children – their 7-year-old daughter is currently in school and they have a 3-year-old son. His plan for the family is to improve their living conditions. Helman has been working in agriculture for five years. The biggest difficulty that it has presented to him is the lack of technical advising because he does not know how to apply fertilizers well to lost produce. He started this business on his own and his future plan for his farming is to have better production. With the loan, he will purchase fertilizers so that he can have better production.

Translated from Spanish by Kathleen O'Connell, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy supplies and fertilizers to improve production.

loans.name: Jose Manuel

texts.es: El es originario de la comunidad de paqui con cariño le dice don manuelito su principal fuente de ingreso es la venta de productos diario, hoy necesita de un credito la cual sera invertido en la compra de tarjetas telefonicas  de las diferentes compañias, por ser una de las demandas de los jovenes y señoritas por dicho lugar se encuentra un instituto por cooperativa, la cual el manifiesta que debe de aprovechar  esa occaccion para poder mejora su nivel de vida y la de su familia con la venta.
texts.en:
He is from the Paqui community. Manuelito affectionately explains that his primary source of income is from selling daily needs products. He now needs a loan to buy telephone cards from different companies. They are in demand by the young men and young ladies from the cooperative institute near his place. He feels he should take advantage of this sales opportunity to be able to improve his level of life and his family’s.

Translated from Spanish by Ginny Kalish, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buy articles of daily consumption

loans.name: Lourdes

texts.es: Lourdes que en estos momentos cuenta con 31 años vive en  su propia casa, ubicada en la Urb. El cairo, junto a su esposo el codeudor con 34 años y sus tres hijos de 11-7-3 años de edad.   Lourdes trabaja como costurera en su casa a pequeña escala y su esposo el codeudor como cargador de productos terminados en aceite fino, ambos con sus buenos años de experiencia en dichas actividades. La competencia es mediana en cuanto a la costura, ya que ella tiene sus clientes conocidos. En cuanto a su esposo no tiene ya que el es asalariado y por ende seguro. Lourdes invirtió en la compra de materiales de construcción. Este es el tercer préstamo de Lourdes y los dos anteriores los canceló dentro del plazo establecido. No tiene deuda en ninguna otra institución financiera.
texts.en:
Lourdes is 31 years old and lives in her own home located in Urb. El Cairo. Together with her husband, who is 34 years old and the cosigner of this loan, they have three children (ages 11, 7, and 3). She works from her small house as a seamstress. Her husband delivers refined petroleum products. The both have years of experience in their respective occupations. The competition from other tailoring business is about average, but fortunately Lourdes knows her regular clients. Her husband does not have that problem because he is a salaried employee and has a secure income.

Lourdes will purchase building materials. This is her third loan and her previous loans were repaid on time. She does not have any debts with other financial institutions.

Translated from Spanish by Ronan Reodica, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase construction materials

loans.name: Anu

texts.en:
Mrs. Anu S., 29-years-old, is a tailor in the town of Thikedewal in Lalitpur. She opened her tailoring shop three years ago. Her specialty is making custom-fitted ladies' dresses and school uniforms for both boys and girls. She prefers to make popular dresses like Kurta Salwar, blouses, ladies' long dresses, Makhshi and others. 

Before starting her own business, Mrs. S. took a six-month training course in tailoring. Now, Mrs. S. is requesting a NPR 15,000 loan to buy raw materials for her work. Mrs. S. lives in a single family with her husband and son. Her husband's name is Mr. Sanjay S. and he works in his own workshop. She has one son, who is studying in primary school.

loans.use: To buy raw materials for her work

loans.name: Resa

texts.en:
Resa O.'s main source of income comes from making and selling specialty food products in her community. She is 37 years old, married and has three school-age children.They are from the village of Dalipuga, Iligan City. Resa has been in business for over three years and earns approximately 5,000 PHP a month.

In 2009, Resa joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living conditions and enable her to engage in business activities. Resa is requesting a loan of 5,000 PHP which will be used to purchase raw ingredients needed to make products for sale. This will be her first loan from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue to improve and expand her business.

About HSPFI: HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase raw ingredients needed to make products for sale

loans.name: Nena

texts.en:
Nena R. is from Bañadero, Ozamiz City. She is 61 years old, married with 5 adult-aged children. To make a living, she owns and operates a sari-sari store business, selling a variety of products to local community. She has been engaged in this business for over 6 years and earns approximately 10,000.00 PHP a month.

In September 2006, she joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to improve her living condition and ability to engage in business activities. She has successfully repaid a previous loan from PMPC with the amount of 40,000.00 PHP.She is now requesting a new loan of 50,000.00 PHP which will be used to buy more variety of products to sell to her neighbors. This will be her 8th loan availment from PMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve their living standard and to live with a healthy life.

loans.use: use to buy more grocery stocks

loans.name: Esther

texts.en:
Esther M. is 43 years of age, married with five children. She lives in Gasabo district, outside the capital city of Kigali in Rwanda. Here, she operates a shoe sales business.  Esther has been successfully selling shoes since 2006. She employs two persons from her community and her shop is open every day from 7AM to 6PM.

Esther is requesting her first loan from Vision Finance Company in order to expand her business through purchasing a greater variety of shoes to reach a wider base of customers and serve her existing customers even better.

loans.use: More shoes types and as working capital

loans.name: Poni

texts.en:
Poni M. sells maize flour and groundnut paste. She requests a loan to purchase charcoal to sell.  Poni is 35 years old and is married to a peasant. She has six children and her children go to school.  With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to build a house for her family and provide enough food.

BRAC's holistic approach to poverty alleviation and empowerment of the poor encompasses a range of core programs in economic and social development, health, education, human rights and legal services which are delivered through an extensive network of village organizations. BRAC has become one of the world's largest NGOs as measured by the scale and diversity of its interventions.  In 2007, BRAC started operations in Southern Sudan. The microfinance program, which is targeted towards returning war refugees, has already formed 418 village organizations with more than 14,000 women members.

loans.use: To purchase bags of charcoal to sell

loans.name: Melodina

texts.en:
Melodina D. is from the village of Tumpagon, a barangay in Cagayan De Oro City on Mindanao. She is 33 years old, married and has five school-aged children. Melodina sells specialty food products from her food stall to the local community. Melodina has been engaged in her business for over eight years and earns approximately 7,000 PHP a month.

In 2008, Melodina joined HSPFI to gain access to its financial services. She is requesting a loan, her fourth, of 11000 PHP from HSPFI which she will use to purchase additional products to sell. Melodina successfully repaid a previous loan of 11,000 PHP from HSPFI, which was used to buy ingredients for the food she sells. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from her business to pay for her children’s education.

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is an accredited partner of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that one-on-one translations of entrepreneur profiles are costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow it to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional products to sell.

location.town: Tumpagon, Cagayan de Oro, Misamis Oriental

loans.name: Wusuk

texts.en:
Wusuk G. is currently in the business of selling beans, tomatoes, and groundnut paste and is requesting a loan to stock more bags of beans and groundnut paste to sell.  Wusuk is 39 years old and is widowed. She has five children and her children go to school. With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to build a house for renting.

BRAC's holistic approach to poverty alleviation and empowerment of the poor encompasses a range of core programs in economic and social development, health, education, human rights and legal services which are delivered through an extensive network of village organizations. BRAC has become one of the world's largest NGOs as measured by the scale and diversity of its interventions. In 2007, BRAC started operations in Southern Sudan. The microfinance program, which is targeted towards returning war refugees, has already formed 418 village organizations with more than 14,000 women members.

loans.use: To buy more beans and groundnut paste to sell.

loans.name: La Esperanza Group

texts.es:
El presente comité se encuentra, en su décimo primer ciclo. Podemos hablar de la Sra. Carmen Cáceres con 35 años de edad, tiene 3 hijos tiene venta de productos  de limpieza en los almacenes del barrio de la ciudad de Lambaré  y en los puestos sanitarios y en otras localidades cercanas, lo realiza en la hora de la tarde  y regresa a su casa ya cuando oscurece .
Es una señora muy guapa y valiente porque lucha para el día a día y así poder salir adelante con sus hijos ya que es madre soltera.   
Lo que anhela  es tener su propio local. De esta manera ella sostiene los gastos de la casa y de  sus dos hijos que estudian. 
Como ella las demás integrantes también realizan sus actividades diariamente así como: 
Nombre y Apellido
Actividad
Griselda T..Venta de merceria
Arminda A..Reciclajes
Silvia A..Venta de carbon
Mara luz C..Vta  de comida
Cynthia A..Venta de Ropas
Gladys T..Venta de frutas 
Antonia T..Venta de comestible
Isabel Gonzalez.Venta de empanadas
Ramona R..Venta de ropas
Florentina B..Modista
Andrea R..Modista
Clara S..Venta de Quiniela
Carmen C..Venta de producto de limpieza
Rocio Gonzalez.Venta deAvon
Jessica agüero.Venta de lenceria 
Yolanda S..Venta de tortas
Mercedes Castiglione.Venta de ropas
texts.en:
The group is currently in their eleventh loan cycle. Let’s talk about Carmen Cáceres. She is 35, and she has three children. She sells cleaning products in the neighborhood stores in Lambaré. She also sells to bathroom locations and other nearby locations. She does this in the afternoons, and she returns home when it gets dark. She is a great and brave person because she fights day to day to get her children ahead. She is a single mother. She longs to have her own location. That way she could manage the household expenses and the educational expenses for her two children. She is like the other members who also work daily at activities like: Griselda T..Sells Notions Arminda A..Recycles Silvia A..Sells Coal Mara luz C..Sells Food Cynthia A..Sells Clothes Gladys T..Sells Fruit Antonia T.. Sells Food Isabel Gonzalez.Sells Empanadas Ramona R..Sells Clothes Florentina B..Stylist Andrea R..Stylist Clara S..Sells Sports Lottery Tickets Carmen C..Sells Cleaning Products Rocio Gonzalez.Sells Avon Jessica Agüero.Sells Lingerie Yolanda S..Sells Cakes Mercedes Castiglione.Sells Clothes

Translated from Spanish by Ginny Kalish, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buy fabric, ingredients for food, cosmetics, and cleaning products

loans.name: Sovannarith

texts.en:
Mr. Sovannarith S., 44 and his wife, Mrs. Chantha Bo, 44, were married in 1986 and have four daughters. One of them is a garment factory worker and another two attend school. The family lives in a village along national road number one, approximately twenty kilometers from Phnom Penh. Sovannarith was not in the photo, his wife in pictured instead.

Sovannarith has been a construction worker for four years. He now wants to launch his own business as a construction contractor but doesn’t have enough materials. Therefore, he is asking for a first loan of $400 to purchase construction materials for his business.

loans.use: To purchase construction materials.

loans.name: Ou

texts.en:
Ou V., 58, is married and lives with her two children in Takeo Province, Cambodia. She is in the business of weaving Cambodian traditional silk, earning an income of US$6.60 per day. She has been in this business since 1998. Her husband is a farmer raising livestock at home on his own plot of farmland, earning US$0.60 per day. V. is shown with her husband in the photo.

V. and her family members try to work hard and help each other to ensure a good standard of living for the family. And they are seeking to improve their businesses as well, so as to provide for the necessary daily expenses. Therefore, V. is requesting for a loan of US$1,100 from CREDIT, Kiva’s partner. She wants to use the loan to buy more raw silk to produce Cambodian traditional silk for her new and existing customers. This is her first loan from CREDIT.

loans.use: To buy more raw silk to weave

loans.name: Bertha Luz

texts.es:
La señora Bertha, pertenece al Banco Comunal “Honestidad y trabajo, Distrito D. Juanjui, Provincia D. Mariscal Cáceres, Departamento D. San Martín. Es Casada, tiene 47 años y 04 hijos, 02 que aun dependen D. ella y están estudiando, presenta estudios D. Secundaria Completa.

Bertha, Lleva 13 años dedicándose a la confección D. vestidos y poco a poco fue generando sus propios ingresos y ahorrando su dinero. Anteriormente se dedicaba a la venta D. abarrotes.
